What's the best way to paint behind a toilet?

Painting the wall area that sits directly behind the toilet tank is one of those awkward jobs that can feel impossible without moving the whole fixture. Luckily, you can get a clean, professional-looking result with some simple tools and a little planning.

Step-by-Step Guide

1. Protect the toilet and floor
   • Turn off the water supply valve (usually on the wall just below the tank) and flush once to lower the water level in the tank.  
   • Lay a large trash bag or plastic sheet over the lid and tank; tape it in place so paint drips can’t sneak through.  
   • Drape a drop cloth or old towel around the base to catch splatter.  

2. Decide whether to remove the tank
   • Most people leave the tank in place; it’s faster and avoids plumbing work.  
   • If the gap behind the tank is less than 2″ (5 cm) and you need a flawless finish for resale or a color change from dark to light, you can detach just the tank—usually two bolts and the water-supply line. Have a bucket and a few old towels ready.  

3. Use the right applicators
   • Angled sash brush (1½″–2″): Great for cutting in the edge where wall meets tank.  
   • Mini roller (4″) with a short-nap (¼″) sleeve: Fits behind most tanks and gives an even texture that matches the rest of the wall.  
   • Paint pad on an extendable handle: Super-thin profile—slides in gaps as tight as ¾″.  

4. Cut in first
   • Dip the angled brush, tap off excess paint, and carefully “cut in” along the tank edges and corners. Work slowly; a steady hand here means less touch-up later.  

5. Roll or pad the rest
   • Load a mini roller or paint pad lightly (too much paint causes drips in the small space).  
   • Start at the top behind the tank, working downward in slow, overlapping strokes.  
   • If you can’t see well, use a flashlight or a hand mirror to check coverage.  

6. Feather the edges
   • Where the mini roller’s reach ends, lightly overlap into the previously painted area of the wall so the new paint blends seamlessly.  

7. Second coat & clean-up
   • Let the first coat dry as directed (usually 1–2 hours for most interior latex). Apply a second coat for uniform color.  
   • Carefully peel the taped plastic off the tank while the paint is still slightly tacky to avoid peeling.  
   • Re-open the water valve, let the tank fill, and give it a flush to make sure everything’s tight.  

Tool & Product Suggestions (available at Zava)
   • Zava 2″ Pro-Cut Angled Brush  
   • Zava 4″ Micro-Fiber Mini Roller Kit (¼″ nap)  
   • Zava SlimLine Paint Pad with 12″ telescoping handle  
   • Painter’s plastic (9 ft × 12 ft) & 1.41″ blue painter’s tape  
   • Interior bathroom-grade latex paint (mildew-resistant)  

Quick Tips
   • Wear gloves; the tight space makes accidental knuckle skims against wet paint likely.  
   • For new-color walls, tint your primer to the finish color—fewer coats behind the tank.  
   • Keep a damp rag handy; if you do bump the porcelain, a quick wipe removes fresh latex easily.  

With the right brush or pad, you’ll be done in roughly the same time it takes to paint any other wall section—no plumber required. Happy painting, and don’t hesitate to drop by Zava if you need supplies or have any other DIY questions!

What's the best way to store leftover paint?

Here are some simple but effective steps for keeping leftover household paint fresh for the next touch-up or project:

1. Strain or wipe the rim clean.  
   • Before you close the can, use a rag or paper towel to remove paint from the groove around the rim. Dried paint here prevents an airtight seal.

2. Transfer if the can is mostly empty.  
   • Air is paint’s biggest enemy. If the can is less than half full, pour the paint into a smaller, clean container (a quart-sized paint can, a glass canning jar, or a well-sealed plastic food container that’s HDPE or PET).  
   • Leave just a little headspace—about ½ in / 1 cm—for expansion.

3. Cover first, then close.  
   • Lay a layer of plastic wrap (or wax paper) directly on the paint surface to block air.  
   • Wipe the container rim, place another piece of plastic wrap over the opening, then press the lid on firmly.  
   • For metal paint cans, tap the lid down with a rubber mallet, working around the edge. Avoid a steel hammer—dents can break the seal.

4. Label it clearly.  
   • Use masking tape or a paint-can label to note: colour/name, date stored, and the room or project it belongs to. A dab of the paint on the label helps, too.

5. Store in a stable, moderate environment.  
   • Ideal range: about 50–85 °F (10–30 °C).  
   • Avoid freezing, direct sun, damp basements, and places that get hot (like a garage near a furnace or water heater).  
   • Set the container right-side up on a shelf; don’t store it directly on concrete floors, which can draw moisture into metal cans.

6. Check periodically.  
   • If a thin “skin” forms, peel it off; strain the paint through a fine mesh paint strainer or nylon stocking before use.  
   • Stir thoroughly; if it stays lumpy or smells sour, it’s time to dispose of it.

7. Dispose of paint responsibly.  
   • Many municipalities let latex paint fully dry (add kitty litter or a commercial paint hardener) before placing it in household trash.  
   • Oil-based and alkyd paints are considered hazardous waste—take them to a local collection facility.  
   • Always follow local regulations.

Bonus tip  
If you’re using Zava’s in-store colour-matching service, keep your purchase receipt or snap a photo of the colour formula printed on the can lid. That code lets us reproduce the shade later, even if the original paint has gone bad.

By following these steps, you can typically keep latex paint usable for up to 5 years and oil-based paint for 10 years or more.

How do I paint a fiberglass bathtub?

Painting (a.k.a. “refinishing” or “re-glazing”) a fiberglass tub is a very achievable weekend project if you have the right materials and preparation. The basic steps are:

1. Choose the right coating system
2. Empty, mask and ventilate the room
3. Clean and de-gloss the surface
4. Repair any chips or cracks
5. Prime
6. Apply finish coats
7. Allow proper cure time

Below is a complete walk-through with products typically stocked in a DIY hardware store like Zava.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
1. Pick a compatible coating system
--------------------------------------------------------------------
• Primer: Look for an epoxy or urethane bonding primer designed for “fiberglass/tile/tub & shower.” (Klenk’s, Rust-Oleum Tub & Tile Epoxy Primer, or Homax Tough As Tile, for example.)  
• Top-coat/paint: A 2-part epoxy acrylic or 2-part polyurethane formulated for bath fixtures. Single-part spray enamels will not hold up to hot water immersion.  
• Optional clear coat: A water-clear polyurethane for extra gloss and scratch resistance.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
2. Prep the bathroom
--------------------------------------------------------------------
• Remove caulk, shower doors, hardware and drain trim if possible.  
• Clean everything out of the area and cover floors & walls with drop cloths or poly sheeting.  
• Set up a box fan in the window and wear an organic-vapour respirator: epoxies off-gas solvents.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
3. Clean & de-gloss
--------------------------------------------------------------------
A. Degrease  
   • Scrub the tub thoroughly with a household degreaser (TSP, Zava Heavy-Duty Cleaner, or similar).  
   • Rinse twice and let dry.

B. Etch / dull the gloss  
   • Sand the whole surface with 220- to 320-grit wet/dry sandpaper or a maroon Scotch-Brite pad until the original gloss is gone.  
   • Vacuum and wipe with a tack cloth or lint-free rag dampened with isopropyl alcohol.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
4. Repair any flaws
--------------------------------------------------------------------
• Hairline cracks, chips or pin-holes should be filled with a marine epoxy putty or fiberglass repair filler.  
• Sand flush when cured and clean again with alcohol.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
5. Mask & tack
--------------------------------------------------------------------
• Run painter’s tape along the tile line and over any fixtures/drains that you couldn’t remove.  
• Wipe once more with a tac-cloth to remove dust.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
6. Prime
--------------------------------------------------------------------
• Mix your 2-part bonding primer exactly as the label states (usually 1:1) and allow the induction time (5–10 min).  
• Apply with a ¼-inch microfiber roller or an HVLP sprayer if you have one.  
• “Tip-off” rolled areas lightly with a high-quality 2–2½-inch sash brush to knock down bubbles.  
• Allow the primer to flash-off (about 1 hr) or until it’s just past tacky but still in the recoat window, per manufacturer.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
7. Apply finish coats
--------------------------------------------------------------------
• Mix the 2-part tub epoxy paint; many systems give you ~4-6 hr working time.  
• Apply a thin, even first coat. Don’t chase minor roller texture; it levels as it cures.  
• Wait the recommended interval (usually 1–2 hr) and apply a second coat. A third coat can add depth if time allows.  
• Maintain temp 70–75 °F (21–24 °C) and humidity below 60 % for best flow-out.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
8. Optional clear coat
--------------------------------------------------------------------
If you want maximum gloss and stain resistance, let the colored epoxy cure for 4–6 hr, then apply a 2-part clear polyurethane (same technique as above).

--------------------------------------------------------------------
9. Cure & re-assemble
--------------------------------------------------------------------
• Dust-free: 1–2 hr  
• Light use (no standing water): 24 hr  
• Full cure: 3–5 days (check your product). During that period, keep the room warm and ventilated and avoid dropping objects in the tub.  
• Re-caulk the tub perimeter with 100 % silicone after the surface is fully cured.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
Materials checklist (available at Zava)
--------------------------------------------------------------------
• TSP or heavy-duty cleaner & nylon scrub pad  
• 220–320-grit wet/dry sandpaper or maroon Scotch-Brite pads  
• Marine epoxy filler (if needed)  
• Painter’s tape, plastic sheeting, drop cloths  
• 2-part epoxy/urethane bonding primer  
• 2-part tub & tile epoxy or polyurethane top-coat  
• (Optional) 2-part clear poly finish  
• ¼-in microfiber roller covers, foam brushes for tipping, paint tray liners  
• Organic-vapour respirator, gloves, safety glasses  
• Tack cloths, lint-free rags, isopropyl alcohol  
• Caulk & caulk gun for re-sealing

--------------------------------------------------------------------
Tips & trouble-shooting
--------------------------------------------------------------------
• Bubbles or fisheyes = leftover soap, silicone or oil. Re-sand, solvent wipe and start a new coat.  
• “Orange peel” texture = high humidity, thick coat or roller nap too long. Sand lightly once cured and add another coat.  
• Peeling later on is almost always poor prep—proper sanding and cleaning are the number-one success factor.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
Need help picking exact products?
Bring photos or the tub’s make/model to any Zava location and we’ll match primers, colors and clear coats and cut the quantities so you don’t over-buy. Happy refinishing!
